summary: the genus Rubus is very diverse, includes over 750 species in 12 subgenera, and is found on all continents except Antarctica. the leaf extract of R. fairholmianus (R. moluccanus L.) collected in the early morning has been used by Koch-Rajbongshi and Rangia tribes to reduce headache by [3] the leaves have been reported to possess insecticidal properties; fruits are edible and stimulant [4] top ranked compounds have been tested in vitro. the Glide score, number of H-bonds, distance of bonds, interacted protein residues, and ligand atom were observed from docking studies. negative control was prepared by adding 100 L of methanol in 5 mL of 0.1 mM methanolic solution of DPPH. the tubes were allowed to stand for 20 minutes at 27°C. total antioxidant activity measured by ABTS radical cation decolourization assay. l acetate (9 : 1, 7 : 3, 6 : 4, 5 : 5, 4 : 6, 2 : 8), chloroform: methanol (8 : 2, 6 : 4, 5 : 5, 4 : 6), diethyl ether (100%), ethanol (100%), methanol (100%), acetic acid (2%), and acetone (100%) a total of 183 fractions were collected and the fractions with similar chemical profiles were clubbed. the bands visualized under UV at 254 nm and 366 nm were scrapped out and dissolved in respective solvents. the time based collection was performed using preparative fraction collector on Agilent 1200 high pressure liquid chromatographic system. mass spectrometry LC-ESI-MS analysis was conducted on Agilent 6520 accurate mass Q-TOF LC/MS coupled with Agilent LC 1200 equipped with Extend-C18 column of 1.8 m, 2.1 50 mm. Gradient elution was performed with methanol (solvent A, 70%) and 0.1% formic acid (solvent B, 30%) at a constant flow rate of 0.3 mL/min. the retrieved protein has been prepared for docking using Protein Preparation Wizard. the grid was generated for the prepared proteins. commercially available drugs and newly isolated compounds were docked against BRCA and COX proteins. docked complex was examined with an emphasis on visual rather than numerical appraisal. 2.7. Statistical Analysis All the values are expressed as mean SEM. antioxidant capacity (TEAC) assay The total antioxidant activity was measured by ABTS radical cation decolourization assay according to Re et al. [21] the percentage inhibition was calculated against the blank (ethanol) with an absorbance at 734 nm and then was plotted as a function of Trolox concentration. the extract (50 g) was eluted on activated silica gel (230–400 mesh) in toluene. 183 fractions were collected and the fractions with similar banding pattern were clubbed. the 4 active fractions yielded 6 subfractions: methanol and ethyl acetate subfractions of F5 (F5M and F5EA), methanol and diethyl ether subfractions of 16 (F16M and F16DE) all these fractions were analysed by TLC, HPLC, and so forth. the bioactive compound was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and scanned in the range of 4000–400 cm1. 2.5.3. FTIR spectrum was recorded using a Nicolet 5700 (Thermo electron, Madison, WI, USA) spectrometer at room temperature. bioactive compound was dissolved in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and scanned in the range of 4000–400 cm1. we have employed flexible docking strategies in this study to identify the most suitable ligand binging sites in the BRCA and COX target proteins. flexible molecular docking operations require no prior knowledge of the ligand conformation. ,4-dimethyl phenol, isopentyl benzoate or 3-methylpentyl benzoate, 4-methylpentyl benzoate, 2-(isopentyloxycarbonyl) benzoic acid, 2-(5-methylhexyl) benzoic acid, and 1-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-4-methyl pentan-1-one isolated from R. fairholmianus root acetone extract were screened for their inhibitory activity against B diclofenac, indomethacin, paracetamol, aspirin, and morphine are the commercially available standard drugs for the treatment of cancer. about 6 compounds such as 3(imino methyl)-2,4-dimethyl phenol, isopentyl benzoate or 3-methylpentyl benzoate, 4-methylpentyl benzoate, 2-(isopentyloxycarbonyl) benzoic acid, 2-(5- DPPH and ABTS radical scavenging activities of fractions and compounds of R. fairholmianus were evaluated using DPPH and ABTS radical scavenging assays. IC50 values of the isolated compounds ranged between 12.35 and 3.23 g/mL. no previous reports are available on DPPH radical scavenging activity. phenolic compounds in berries have been well characterized as natural antioxidants. the DPPH and ABTS radical scavenging activity of an allied species has also been reported. the isolated compounds and fractions of R. fairholmianus root acetone extract have a commendable antioxidant activity in the tested assays. the molecular formula of this compound was established based on the mass spectrum MS (m/z) [M-H]: 235.12. The structure was confirmed as cis-2-(isopentyloxycarbonyl) benzoic acid. the structure was confirmed as cis-2-(isopentyloxycarbonyl) benzoic acid. [3-(Iminomethyl)-2,4-dimethylphenol] white crystals (10.58 mg) obtained from F16. many reports available on phytochemical characterization and activity guided studies of the related species of Rubus. most of the compounds isolated from the Rubus species belong to cyanidin type compounds, anthocyanins, and tannins. cyanidin-3-glucoside, cyanidin-3-rutinoside, cyanidin-3-sambubioside, cyanidin-3-xylosylrutinoside, pelargonidin-3-glucoside, and pelargonidin-3-rutinoside. standard drugs such as doxorubicin and letrazole also showed high binding with active site of BRCA1 protein followed by 2-[(3-methylbutoxy the docking results of BRCA1 revealed that the mode of molecular interactions of the isolated compounds and standard drugs was almost similar. 1-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-4-methylpentan-1-one and 4-methylpentyl benzoate also showed fairly good binding affinities towards the target protein BRCA2. the docking score of the standard drugs falls between 2.0 and 4.82. the docking results of BRCA2 with the isolated compounds were closely related to standard drugs. the information gained from this study will be useful for further development of novel breast cancer inhibitors.
